message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and cervical motion tenderness, which are all symptoms of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Urinary tract infection can cause fever but usually does not cause lower abdominal pain and cervical motion tenderness. Vaginitis and cervicitis do not typically cause severe lower abdominal pain and adnexal tenderness, and the purulent discharge suggests a deeper infection such as PID. The negative urine pregnancy test also rules out ectopic pregnancy as a cause of the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including lower abdominal pain, fever, and cervical motion tenderness, suggest pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). The presence of purulent discharge on speculum examination also supports this diagnosis. Vaginitis may cause discharge and irritation but is not usually associated with severe lower abdominal pain. Cervicitis may cause cervical motion tenderness but is not associated with purulent discharge or severe lower abdominal pain. Urinary tract infection may cause fever and abdominal pain but is not associated with cervical motion tenderness or purulent discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) which is characterized by inflammation of the upper genital tract. The positive cervical motion tenderness and inflamed cervix support this diagnosis. Vaginitis and cervicitis are less likely to cause diffuse lower abdominal pain and adnexal tenderness. A negative urine pregnancy test excludes ectopic pregnancy, but a more specific test for pregnancy (such as serum beta-hCG) should be considered as well. Urinary tract infections typically do not cause cervical motion tenderness or uterine tenderness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, past sexual history, and physical examination findings suggest pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), an infection in the female reproductive organs. Vaginitis only affects the vagina, while cervicitis only affects the cervix. Urinary tract infection may cause lower abdominal pain, but the presence of cervical motion tenderness and uterine and adnexal tenderness suggest a gynecological infection such as PID.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Vaginitis is inflammation of the vagina and cervicitis is inflammation of the cervix, but neither would explain the severe abdominal pain and guarding. A urinary tract infection would not explain the cervical motion tenderness and purulent discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), particularly the severe lower abdominal pain with guarding, inflamed cervix with cervical motion tenderness, and purulent discharge. Vaginitis and cervicitis can cause vaginal discharge and cervical inflammation, but do not typically cause the severe abdominal pain and tenderness. Urinary tract infection may cause fever and abdominal pain, but would not have the cervical findings seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs, especially the severe lower abdominal pain with guarding and uterine and adnexal tenderness, suggest pelvic inflammatory disease. All other options do not present with the same symptoms and signs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of fever, malaise, nausea, and abdominal pain with positive cervical motion tenderness and an inflamed cervix suggest pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). The other options, such as vaginitis, cervicitis, and urinary tract infection, do not include these findings. The negative pregnancy test also rules out ectopic pregnancy as a cause of the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) which includes lower abdominal pain, fever, and tenderness on cervical motion. The yellow-white purulent discharge suggests cervicitis. While UTI and vaginitis may cause some overlapping symptoms, they do not fully match the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which is commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and gonorrhea. Vaginitis and cervicitis do not typically present with severe lower abdominal pain and adnexal tenderness. A urinary tract infection can cause fever and nausea, but it is unlikely to cause the other symptoms described by the patient. The presence of cervical motion tenderness and purulent discharge on examination supports the diagnosis of PID.
